Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Label-free imaging for real-time, intraoperative blood vessel visualization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a novel, intraoperative imaging technology to address the problem of inadvertent cuts to vasculature during minimally invasive surgeries. More than 17% of patients who undergo these types of in-patient surgeries suffer from an intraoperative bleeding event. When a vessel is injured, there is a higher probability of hospital borne infection due to the loss of blood, and the added cost of care per patient increases by thousands of dollars due to corrective action and extended length of stay for the patient. The risk of vascular injury is compounded by risk factors, such as obesity, which limit the surgeon's ability to visualize and navigate vasculature. Therefore, there is a critical need to identify and assess hidden vasculature in real time. The proposed technology helps identify blood vessel before a cut is made. Importantly, this system will be designed for seamless integration into a suite of surgical instruments for multiple applications. Long term, the company will provide surgeons with the preeminent imaging platform to view, assess, and characterize a range of vessels (i.e. arteries/veins, ureters and bile ducts) in real-time for improved surgical guidance and outcomes.

The proposed project will develop a novel blood vessel detection and visualization platform using low-cost optical imaging sensors and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The proposed technology will provide visual and quantitative information about vessel presence and size in real-time that can supplement a surgeon's technique. This system will be simple, cost-effective, easy to employ, and highly accurate. Traditionally, the avoidance of blood vessels during minimally invasive surgery is accomplished by visualization or costly intraoperative imaging. The proposed technology will use pulsatile light absorption characteristics of blood vessels to provide quantitative information about vessel presence and size in real-time, supplementing a surgeon's technique. This project will also add significant value to the body of research conducted in the areas of signal processing and image analysis. In addition, the proposed technology will remove the risk of data loss due to artifacts in general and motion artifacts in particular. The proposed technology will be validated ex vivo and in vivo using a porcine animal model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to create an unobtrusive optical technology that will facilitate the detection and visualization of blood vessels during surgery.  With the increased use of minimally invasive surgical (MIS) techniques, challenges in blood vessel detection and perioperative management of bleeding complications during these procedures have emerged. The inability to palpate for characteristic flow and pulsations within vessels makes identification highly dependent on surgeon experience. Inadvertent cuts into blood vessels cause non-reimbursable hospital costs in excess of $20B in the US every year. To prevent major complications, advanced tools must be created to supplement the techniques of surgeons when identifying the presence of blood vessels that must be avoided or strategically divided.

 

Briteseed has been developing a low-cost, real-time, and unobtrusive technology for vessel detection to address the unmet need of real-time, intraoperative vessel visualization. This system utilizes a combination of low-cost components and advanced optical algorithms to provide real-time blood vessel visualization during minimally invasive surgery (MIS). The rationale behind this research project was to develop a radically new surgical technology based on optical sensing and artificial intelligence that can provide real-time information in the form of a commonly used laparoscopic grasper.  We accomplished all the primary objectives that were initially proposed. We (a) developed a clinically useful, customizable miniaturized dissector (8mm diameter shaft), (b) delivered a software package for signal artifact compensation and automation, and (c) demonstrated high-level performance of the system in a series of ex vivo and in vivo tests. In addition, we further demonstrated integration of the technology platform into an advanced, widely used vessel sealer and showed further miniaturization of the optical subsystem into a 5mm diameter shaft tool.

 

The long-term vision for this technology is to become the standard of use for tissue-sensing during MIS procedures, allowing for a reduced risk of inadvertent damage to many kinds of sensitive structures. Such technology will be useful for patients in more than 6M minimally invasive procedures performed annually in the U.S. The aim of this research is to limit surgical complications, prevent unwanted patient suffering, minimize long hospital stays, and reduce patient mortality.
